title: Smart Contract Blacklisting
description: 悪意のあるスマートコントラクトは、ネットワーク全体の市場の信頼を脅かします。 人々に分散化されたネガティブな評判のシグナルへのアクセスを与えます。

f6_assessments.q0: Cardano needs a project that can deliver the aims of this project. The idea is here, though the plan still has more to be figured out. Perhaps a smaller project would better covering the first 3 months of this plan. Then a detailed project plan to deliver that could be presented for funding.
f6_assessments.q1: Part of the project plan is to hold events to help develop the plan, thus there is significant risk in the later stages which depend on this. Its not clear the proposer themselves have the skills to do smart contract auditing, which whilst they are not specifically proposing to do that part, it would seem useful for the project. A key governance question that has to be asked is, what happens is there is disagreement over whether a contract is safe or not. How do we stop malicious backlisting of a competitor product, who is the arbiter?
f6_assessments.q2: As the scope of the project will really only be set after the information gathering events, progress is hard to audit based on the pre-event proposal. This could be solved by breaking down the proposal into two stages and coming back for the second stage once scope has really been finalized.
f6_assessments.reply: CA explictly states that metrics used to score proposal are outside the scope of the proposal, and so the scores do not reflect content. "...the proposer themselves have the skills to do smart contract auditing, which whilst they are not specifically proposing to do that part..."

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal aims to address one subset of the possible threats that could affect the Cardano blockchain and ecosystem. The proposers have focused on the expected emergence of malicious (also named as scam) smart contracts that can threaten market trust throughout the network. What I think is missing in the proposal - and would strenghten it - is an overview of how serious this problem of malicious (not poorly written smart contracts - but malicious) smart contracts has proven to be in other blockchain systems with smart contracts. The impact can already be asessed in some form - as smart contracts have been present in th blockchain world for years. The severity of this problem would be a great factor that supports developing this system. It is a potential threat - but its importance would need to be indicated through some existing examples. Who uses unvetted contracts in other smart contract systems? What has been the result? Who vets smart contracts in other blockchain systems - which vetting models have already proven to be the best? Why choose this proposed approach and not another? Having in mind that the scope of the proposal is not as wide ranging as the spirit of the challenge [to detect a wide range of threats as blockchain systems are complex amalgam of technological, economic and social components] it needs to be laser-focused on malicious smart contracts - and what has been learned. Maybe the bigger problem is poorly written smart contracts, then maybe that should be specifically included too - or tackled first.
f6_assessments.q1: The milestones seem a bit too difficult to pin down in terms of end size, quality (especially)  and scope. Build a knowledge base for contract transparency... the holding of two summits... Example faucet ... Example wallet integration ... These may be delivered on paper and boxes could be checked - as the milestones are very general ... but there might be no real impact. Hence, I question whether including "Hopefully, a low number of scam contracts : )" would be a good milestone - for a system that aims to detect malicious smart contracts. A low number (or zero) of scam contracts that are able to evade the new system might be a better metric. The proposed Beta wallet integration with a Cardano light/web wallet (e.g. Gamechanger wallet) would be better if it was more specific - which wallet, or how will the wallet be selected. Gamechanger wallet was used as an example. Will it be Gamechanger and why? When I tried to checkout the Team & Partners page for Gamechanger - the site has some generic information on the team ("We are a small team that borned with the building barriers of undeveloped countries and the ones of the Cardano Blockchain's rising ecosystem. We are committed to lower the entry barrier of users, students and builders who want to see their dreams materialized on this young but amazing 3rd Generation Blockchain." ) - but no specifics. It might help to focus on a wallet that is in much wider use. As the system aims to blacklist smart contracts it might be good to build into it some kind of auditing of the whitelist/blacklist registry and a mechanism for smart contract authors to seek corrections of possible mistaken inclusions. The plan states that the proposers "propose that this project will use Gimbalabs Project-Based Learning process and community-based planning" and references  another proposal "to understand why and how we will involve the community in every step of delivering on this proposal: (https://cardano.ideascale.com/a/dtd/NFTs-derisk-Project-Capitalization/368330-48088). However, when I followed through to this other proposal, it states that it has been "Withdrawn". Does this mean that Gimbalabs Project-Based Learning process and community-based planning will not be available for implementing this proposal (it seems to be an integral component). Voters are now not able to consult a component of this proposal - as the other proposal explaining Gimbalabs Project-Based Learning process and community-based planning has apparently been withdrawn. The team does seem to have the qualifications for delivering this proposal, but I think that its presentation and deliverables could be improved to maximize its chances if it is not adopted in this round. The budget seems suitable, but I do not see a lot of planning for future maintenance and iterations and updating of the system - apart from a general comment on "identifying next opportunities for important additions to the protocol and establish a roadmap for further recommendations." I think that a vision of how this would work in the future and be maintained is essential - for it to be ultimately successful.
f6_assessments.q2: As I mentioned above some weaknesses have crept through in the proposal, such as a milestone of "Hopefully, a low number of scam contracts : )" - I think that a very efficient system would be more impactful if it aims for a high detection rate. To make it clear, with the milestone "a low number of scam contracts" if the system does end up detecting a low number of scam contracts - this would be defined as success. But it may also be due to the lack of understanding of malicious contracts, lack of a good methodology or lack of expertise. So, scam contracts may be widespread - but the new system tells us there is a low number of scam contracts as it does not detect them. Success? Additional clarity is lost as the project plans to use Gimbalabs Project-Based Learning process and community-based planning - referenced from a different proposal that has been Withdrawn. If the other proposal is not material, maybe it should not be linked. This makes auditability difficult. Good things I would draw attention to is the teams expertise of the team. I just feel that this is a rushed proposal that could benefit from more sharpness, more focus and more answers (less questions). Such as the the proposed topics for the two summits: Smart Contract Developer Ecosystem & Trust Summit (identify how we flag, how we search the blockchain, how do applications digest flagged contract data/interrupt contract transactions) and SPO & Decentralized Service Deployment Summit (Who will host this service?  Do we allow for paid channels/services?  What does that look like?). I think that this proposal needs to come up with some proposed answers to these problems and not leave them to Summits especially as it is not clear who will attend, who will be invited and whether these Summits (what is a Summit anyway, exactly?) can answer these questions that are of critical importance for the success of this proposal.
f6_assessments.reply: Auditability rationale suggests that accomplishing summits isn't an  auditable action, when its a primary focus of the proposal.  Auditability would be whether or not the summit occured and any insights were shared with the community.

f6_assessments.q0: The cryptocurrency world is currently riddled with scams casting a shadow of doubt on all the crypto community and drawing in the regulator eyes upon it. If nothing is done we risk regulation by incompetent exterior agencies that would hinder innovation and treat us a children who cannot take care of themselves. This proposal would be a great first step into taking the matter into our own hands and creating a layer of trust between our users and the blockchain, shielding them from bad selfish actors trying to defraud people. In this aspect this proposal is a perfect fit for this challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
The "Detailed plan" section includes another proposal as a dependency but the said proposal was withdrawn from fund 6. However, the proposers explained in the comments that the delivery of this proposal will not be impacted, leaving this link was a mistake that should not influence the perception of this proposal (check the comment section of the proposal for more details).

This project is mostly research focused with a technical plan yet to be detailed, therefore it's difficult to evaluate it's feasibility. Nonetheless, the team seems highly competent (from their LinkedIn profiles) and well organized to deliver such a project. Moreover the cost is quite low and the potential benefit very high for the community. The main proposer is very active in the community (Swarm sessions, Gimbalab) and therefore accountable.

There is a budget but it's not very detailed. This and the lack of technical steps even in the organization of the two summits they want to do is not helpful. How will they make sure they have enough attendance to make these summits worthwhile? What is the precise cost breakdown of each summit?

Even if unsuccessful it is asking the right questions and will make our community reflect, progress and discover solutions to this very real threat so in my personal opinion it's a risk worth taking. I therefore set a score of 4 for this feasibility criteria.
f6_assessments.q2:
The problem and solution are well articulated and easy to understand and there is a detailed plan of deliverables. However there is a lack of technical documentation and real actionable steps for each of the described milestones. Some technical documentation would have been welcomed to strengthen each general step.
Technically, the project itself is feasible and does not involves any unknown technologies (I am a developer myself). Plenty of whitelist and blacklist system already exist to filter out websites so we know it's possible and there exist many good ways of implementing them, decentralized or not (an initial implementation would not need decentralization to be already useful).

Given the above I give a score of 4 out of 5 concerning this auditability criteria.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal aims to address the challenge of how to deal with malicious actors in a decentralized architecture. A summit for developers of wallet and DAO developers will be planned to gain insights into a better trust model and user-friendly API services.  Stakepool Operators (SPOs) will be engaged in the development of decentralized deployment strategies.  It is critical that we find a set of trust interpretations and flagging algorithms that limit false positives (false scam reports) and maximize community utility, transparency, deployability.
f6_assessments.q1: The team members on this proposal are highly skilled and able to implement the proposal. The plan is detailed, but may be a bit ambitious and still has a few unknowns that need to be determined which include a lot of community participation.
f6_assessments.q2: This proposal has a reasonable budget with milestones that can be audited - summits completed, wallet integration, while list/blacklist completed. The difficulty entails identifying 'scam' contracts or projects and the metric of measuring consumer trust of Cardano.

f6_assessments.q0: They are clearly addressing a serious problem, i.e. trust in the system and proposes a realistic solution using a community driven approach and utilising relevant stakeholders.
f6_assessments.q1: There seems to be a clear strategy in terms of engaging with the community and listening to the relevant stakeholders who might have many ideas on this. However, it is not clear why a summit is the best means of getting answers on their answers. It may be necessary to "manually" approach developers and perhaps even learn from the ETH ecosystem in this regard. However, this approach is wise in that it doesn't presume a solution beforehand but is rather agnostic and wants to engage in an iterative process which is why it receives a high rating overall.
f6_assessments.q2:
The only weakness is that the justification in terms of budgeting is non-existent. It is unclear why the summit set-up ought to cost $1,500. Presumably it will be online, and will take effort to organise but if it indeed takes this much time to organise, then these costs should be broken down. 

Furthermore, some indication of how the consumer metrics of "Cardano is a blockchain I can trust" will be measured would be good.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal has identified a risk which is on the minds of most developers as Cardano smart contracts launch. In an ecosystem that relies on trust, will bad smart contracts diminish the utlity of the good ones? Standing up a technical solution to this problem by blacklisting, or assessing smart contracts that have been pushed to mainnet does align with the intent of the challenge. For the amount of funds being requested (36% of the fund), this does represent reasonable use of treasury funds.
f6_assessments.q1: The development expertise and background provides solid evidence that the technical deliverables can be met.The proposers (vincent and brandon) are known, worthwhile contributors to the gimbalbs community. What is lacking is sufficient detail on deliverables which was alluded to in a comment by Paymahan which went unanswered by the proposers. This lack of clarity on part of the proposal gives me some pause for thought on the non-technical parts of the proposal (outreach, convening the events), but I have confidence the technical side of the proposal could be delivered within the timeframe specified.
f6_assessments.q2: Some commentary on the risks associated with this proposal would have been useful. The reliance on two events, provides a strong risk that these events won't be able to draw the necessary attention or stakeholders required to make this proposal worthwhile, making the follow up technical components more difficult to complete, and subject to delays. That said, the timeline provided is clear and the funds requested have been adequately accounted for.

f6_assessments.q0: This is an important project to generate trust in good dApps and filter out the bad ones. It should be continued with an automated scanner to identify dApps that have only been superficially altered from known bad ones.
f6_assessments.q1: Some details about the proposed architecture could be provided, however, overall the proposal seems feasible. The proposers appear competent based on their LinkedIn CVs, although examples of past succesful would be helpful.
f6_assessments.q2: Budget is clearly described. Milestones are included, however, since the overall proposed architecture is not clearly described, it is not possible to fully judge how realistic they are and their content.
